content: Q.

tag: html body text p i span a span
content: Ihave read statements attributed to some Buddhist teachers suggesting thatvarious contemporary and historical

tag: html body text p i span span
content: examples of human suffering are theresult of the Karma of those who endure that suffering. Does this mean thatpeople who endure great suffering were deeply unskilful in previous lives andthat those who lead otherwise pleasant lives were skilful people, and if so howis Karma different from the ideas that underpin Caste structures?

tag: html body text p b span span
content: A

tag: html body text p span span
content: .It is believed as the general rule of the law of karma that we are bearing thefruit of our

tag: html body text p span span span
content: actions, whether the result of actions that bring fruit instantly, oractions at any time in the past, or actions in past lives. But always bear inmind that karmic law is not the simplistic two-dimensional principle that weoften think it is. Karmic law is more often than not the expression

tag: html body text p span span
content: ofmulti-dimensional forces that mysteriously interpenetrate and is way beyond themind's ability to comprehend.

tag: html body text p span span
content: Caste systems are manmade, whilst the law of karma is an innate law of nature.

content: Q.

content: Iattempt to sincerely practice the Dharma but have never been able to accept theidea of re-birth either in principle or

tag: html body text p i span span
content: as a matter of faith. I accept thatthe nature of reality is not limited by my capacity to comprehend, but I cannotmake sense of the idea that we are reborn or experience re-becoming. Do youthink this is likely to undermine my efforts to practice and my spiritualprogress? Should I just �sit with it and see'?

content: A.

content: Idon't think you have to make a problem out of it and feel that you are not

tag: html body text p span span span
content: practisingproperly. Practice

tag: html body text p span span
content: is about dealing with where your feet are at this verymoment, and therefore you could say that is all that is necessary. From my ownexperience of getting to know myself over the years of practice, it became

tag: html body text p span span span
content: obviousthat, with all goes that to make me up, with my strong habits and powerfulattachments, it would be quite absurd to imagine that they just materialised outof nothing at birth.

tag: html body text p span span

tag: html body text p b span a span
content: Q.

tag: html body text p i span a span
content: How important is meditation in the spiritual life? The ground of my practice isto be found in ethics, and, given the

tag: html body text p i span span
content: emphasis on meditation, this sometimeshas the effect of making me feel like a second-class Buddhist.

tag: html body text p b span span
content: A.

tag: html body text p span span
content: Peoplewho have this idea that practice is all about sitting merely

tag: html body text p span span span
content: display

tag: html body text p span span
content: their lack of understanding of the complete process that needs to be put inplace for the changes that practice brings about. Yes, you can say that of allthe parts that go

tag: html body text p span span span
content: toward

tag: html body text p span span
content: make acomplete practice, sitting meditation would be the most important part, butsitting will not reach its full potential without the support of the rest of theeightfold path.

tag: html body text p span span span
content: So it is wrong to think

tag: html body text p span span
content: that if you can't sit you can't practice. There are many people dedicated toDharma practice who have difficulty with sitting meditation.

tag: html body text p span span
content: Sorather

tag: html body text p span span
content: than getdisheartened learn to focus on the rest of the path. Ethical practice is theobvious one to focus on, for it is the gateway into the Dharma.

tag: html body text p span span span
content: Come

tag: html body text p span span
content: to realise that while you are refining this aspect of the path you arecultivating the mind in the same way as sitting practice.

tag: html body text p span span
content: Restraining and containingactions, whether they are your thoughts, words or deeds, is possible only byself-awareness. Putting new thoughts, words and deeds into action is onlypossible with that

tag: html body text p span span span
content: same self-awareness.

tag: html body text p span span
content: To do this you need application born of concentration and the understanding thatyour unskilfulness needs to change. Is this not working with the eightfold pathof sila, samadhi, and prajna? What meditation practice will bring to this is adeepening of what you are already doing, but fundamentally there is nodifference.

tag: html body text p span span
content: If you wish to come tomeditation sometime in the future, then adding a devotional practice to anethical one will help bring you more speedily to that

tag: html body text p span span span
content: roundedness.

tag: html body text p span span
content: Devotional practice helps to soften the heart andintroduces us to the side of ourselves that we need to learn to get in contactwith in order for the deeper Dharma to arise. Devotional practice usually startsby projecting outwards to Buddhas and Bodhisattvas, but you should soon realiseyour relationship with this form of external practice is very much conditionedby the inner relationship you have with yourself, and therefore should make youreflect more and more internally.

tag: html body text p span span
content: Change that takes place inpractice does not come from the head but rather from a part of us that we arefor the most part cut off from, that deep emotional seat buried within our body.It is

tag: html body text p span span span
content: this

tag: html body text p span span
content: that we need to becomefamiliar with, and make friends with all that is contained there. There islittle �logic� here.

tag: html body text p span span span
content: It takes faithand trust, becoming familiar with the reality of Dharma practice � which isthe willingness to surrender our profound attachment to the self that imprisonsus in our head and creates the restlessness that prevents quiet meditation beingpossible.

tag: html body text p span span
content: Devotional practice allows us to start that process of becomingwhole. By combining this with your developing ethical stability and skilfulmeans born of self-awareness, you will be transforming the emotional and mentalrestlessness that prevents you from sitting now.

tag: html body text p span span span
content: You will be laying the

tag: html body text p span span
content: foundation for a fruitful sitting practicein the near future.

content: Q

tag: html body text p a i span span
content: .Would you agree with the view that buying meat and fish are the same as eating

tag: html body text p a span i span
content: something that has been killed for

tag: html body text p span i span
content: you � meat and fish are made available for consumers. If you buy it and eat itthen all that you have done is avoided the messy business of killing by payingan anonymous person to do the work for you. So, doesn't buying meat and fishamount in practice to the killing?

tag: html body text p b span span
content: A

tag: html body text p span span
content: .The Buddha wasn't a vegetarian, nor were his vast sangha, including countlessarhants who, like the Buddha, had finished their training and gone beyond thecreation of karma, reaching the pureness of thought, word and action. Thenumerous traditions that sprang up

tag: html body text p span span span
content: inthe East

tag: html body text p span span
content: over more than two thousand years since the Buddha have neverbeen vegetarian, and I don't recall any of the prominent saints and sages ofBuddhism saying that

tag: html body text p span span span
content: to follow theDharma you must be vegetarian.

tag: html body text p span span
content: To suggest, as many do, in the West thatthe first precept is violated by eating meat is to suggest that all those whohave

tag: html body text p span span span
content: practised traditional Buddhism, including the Buddha and the arhants, havebeen in violation of the first precept. I can best suggest you read the recent

tag: html body text p span span
content: postconcerning vegetarianism for my general view on

tag: html body text p span span
content: the subject.

tag: html body text p span span
content: If you wish to create a'moral' view for vegetarianism (or anything else), then it should be based firston the cultural background, and always be a personal view for you alone. Doremember, there will be

tag: html body text p span span span
content: many sincerespiritual people,

tag: html body text p span span
content: and manyfine human beings that don't have a spiritual path, who will disagree withwhatever new ideas you come up with. That's why if you really seek guidance asto what is right and wrong it is best to stay with �rules� that are part ofthe natural laws that govern nature, which are always conditioned by the laws ofkarma.

tag: html body text p span span
content: If we decide to set up newideas and propagate them in the name of

tag: html body text p span span span
content: Buddhistmorality,

tag: html body text p span span
content: we will be setting up a duality, which will always createproblems.

tag: html body text p span span span
content: This will

tag: html body text p span span
content: inevitablybring conflict with those who disagree,

tag: html body text p span span span
content: thusviolating

tag: html body text p span span
content: the basic spirit of Buddhism, which is to accept things the waythey are. Remember, never has there been a conflict in the name of Buddhism in2500 years; do you think that fine record is

tag: html body text p span span span
